concepts.common_misconceptions: Children sometimes think that because they are gentle, handling living things for extended periods is fine. They need to understand that even gentle handling causes stress and that returning animals quickly is important.

concepts.description: Understanding the specific safety rule that one must never look directly at the Sun, even when wearing dark glasses or through a telescope or binoculars, because the intense light can permanently damage the retina and cause blindness. This rule applies during all science work involving observation of the sky, including during seasonal changes observations and any astronomy. This is a rare absolute rule in primary science.
concepts.teaching_guidance: State the rule clearly and repeat it whenever relevant. Ensure pupils understand it is not negotiable and applies even on cloudy days when the Sun appears less bright. Discuss why this rule exists - the concentrated light and ultraviolet radiation can permanently damage the sensitive cells of the retina. Model safe sky observation techniques.
concepts.key_vocabulary: Sun, look, directly, dangerous, eyes, retina, blindness, safe, never, rule
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children commonly believe that dark glasses make it safe to look at the Sun - they do not. Some believe that looking quickly is safe - it is not.

prerequisite_relationships.rationale: Scientific curiosity is the motivational foundation for asking scientific questions. Pupils who are curious about the world are more naturally inclined to ask investigable questions, though question-asking can also be taught without curiosity as a starting point.
Pupils must be able to formulate a scientific question before they can design and carry out an investigation to answer it. The question determines the method, what to change, and what to observe.
Close observation is essential before classification - pupils must be able to notice the features and details of objects before they can use those features as the basis for grouping them.
Identifying similarities and differences is the cognitive basis for classification - you cannot group objects without first recognising what makes them alike or different.
Close, careful observation is required before pupils can identify meaningful similarities and differences between objects. Superficial observation leads to superficial comparison.
Pupils must have carried out observations or tests before they can use the results as evidence to draw conclusions. Evidence-based conclusions require evidence first.
Observations must exist before they can be recorded. The purpose of recording is to capture observations for future reference and communication.
Scientific communication includes communicating conclusions. Pupils need findings to communicate before they can practise communicating them effectively.
Data recording is a foundational form of scientific communication that develops into more sophisticated oral and written communication of findings and explanations.

Comparative testing is one method of answering scientific questions. Pupils must understand that questions can be answered in different ways before appreciating the comparative test as one specific approach.

Basic observation skills are prerequisite for observation over time, which involves the same core skill applied repeatedly across extended periods. You must be able to observe before you can observe systematically over time.
The skill of observing changes over time is an extension of basic observation skill - the same careful attention to detail is required, repeated at intervals with specific focus on what has changed.
Recognising patterns in observations requires careful and detailed observation in the first place. Patterns only emerge when sufficient careful observations have been made.
Using equipment is a means of making better observations. Pupils should first develop basic observation skills before learning to extend those skills using tools.
The skill of making sorting and grouping decisions underpins the classification process. Classification requires the meta-skill of deciding how to group as well as the act of grouping.
Identifying whole plants provides meaningful context for then studying and naming their component parts in detail. Recognition of the whole plant precedes systematic analysis of its structure.

Identifying and naming trees is prerequisite for classifying them into deciduous and evergreen categories. Pupils need to know which trees they are looking at before they can compare their seasonal behaviour.

Understanding plant structures, including what seeds and bulbs are, provides essential foundation for understanding how plants grow from these structures. Knowing the structures precedes understanding their role in growth.
Understanding that seeds are a plant structure is prerequisite for understanding germination as the process by which seeds begin to grow into plants.
Observing plant growth from seeds and bulbs raises the natural question of what plants need to grow successfully, making study of plant requirements a logical next step.

Understanding general plant requirements for growth provides the context for understanding germination requirements specifically. Germination is the first stage of growth and requires a subset of general plant conditions.
The process skill of observation over time is required to observe and understand plant growth from seeds and bulbs, which is a slow process requiring systematic observation over days and weeks.
Knowing and being able to name the five vertebrate groups provides the framework for systematically comparing and contrasting body structures within and between groups.
Understanding the five vertebrate groups provides a useful additional framework for thinking about diet classification, though diet classification can be learned somewhat independently.
The curriculum explicitly links sense organs to senses: pupils must know the names of body parts (eyes, ears, nose, tongue, skin) before they can associate each with its corresponding sense.
Understanding animal life cycles, particularly metamorphosis and development, requires the process skill of observation over time, as the stages unfold across days, weeks or months.
Understanding basic survival needs (water, food, air) provides foundation for understanding what it means to stay healthy. Health requirements build on survival needs to include quality and exercise.

Understanding the distinction between objects and materials is conceptually prerequisite for material identification - pupils need to understand they are naming what something is made from, not what it is.

Pupils must be able to identify and name materials before they can meaningfully describe and compare their properties. You need to know what material you are testing before you can characterise its properties.

Knowledge of material properties is directly prerequisite for judging suitability for purpose. The reasoning for suitability (e.g., 'metal is suitable for a bridge because it is strong and hard') requires knowing that metal has those properties. This is the explicit Year 1 to Year 2 progression in the curriculum.

Identifying materials is prerequisite for exploring how different materials respond to physical forces. Pupils need to know what materials they are working with before they can investigate how those materials behave.

The comparative testing method is the primary way pupils investigate material suitability at KS1. The curriculum explicitly suggests testing questions such as which material is best for a given purpose.

Comparative testing is the method by which pupils investigate plant requirements (comparing plants with and without light, water, or warmth). The process skill enables the content knowledge to be discovered empirically.

Understanding that there are four distinct seasons is the conceptual framework within which seasonal weather patterns can be organised and understood. The seasonal framework precedes associating specific weather with each season.
Understanding the four seasons provides the temporal framework for understanding how day length varies across the year. The seasonal vocabulary is needed to describe when days are longer or shorter.
Observing seasonal weather patterns requires sustained observation over time. The process skill of observing changes over time is required to collect the evidence from which seasonal patterns emerge.
Understanding that deciduous trees lose their leaves in autumn and winter provides a concrete, visible example of seasonal change that supports general understanding of seasonal patterns.

Understanding what life processes are is prerequisite for distinguishing living things (those showing life processes) from dead things (once showed life processes) and things never alive (never showed life processes).

Understanding that animals have basic survival needs is foundational for understanding habitat suitability - a suitable habitat is one that provides for those needs. The concept of needs precedes the concept of their provision by habitat.
Understanding plant requirements for growth supports understanding habitat suitability for plants, which is part of understanding how habitats provide for the needs of all their inhabitants.

Understanding the concept of a habitat is essential before understanding that habitats are suitable for particular organisms. The general concept of habitat precedes the nuanced understanding of habitat-organism fit.

Understanding the concept of habitat as a home for organisms is prerequisite for understanding micro-habitats as very small, localised versions of the same idea. The macro concept precedes the micro concept.
Understanding habitats as communities where multiple organisms live together is foundational for understanding interdependence - that the organisms in a habitat depend on one another.

Understanding diet classification (carnivore/herbivore/omnivore) from Year 1 is essential background for constructing food chains in Year 2. The chain shows who eats whom, which requires knowing each organism's diet category.

Food chains are a specific, formal representation of one type of interdependence (feeding relationships) in a habitat. Understanding general interdependence provides the conceptual context for the food chain model.
Understanding that something is 'living' is prerequisite for understanding habitats as environments where living things reside. The concept of life precedes the concept of where living things live.
Being able to identify plants in their local environment supports identifying plants in specific habitats. Basic plant identification skills apply directly when studying organisms in their habitats.
Knowledge of different animal groups from Year 1 supports identifying animals in habitats in Year 2. The classification framework helps pupils organise and describe the organisms they find.
